channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #166 - A Mild Case of Shellshock
item.description: The main tech news of the week has to be the Shellshock exploit. Does it affect Perl? Fortunately, not that much (David Farrell has the details). In other news, a new version of DBD::SQLite will soon be released, a new Perl book is in the making, and Perl will be participating in the next iteration of the OPW -- all providing us with delightful reasons for looking forward to the months ahead. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Outreach Program for Women - Winter 2014 / 2015
item.description: A new edition of the Outreach Program for Women is rolling in, and Perl is happily involved, Karen Pauley reports.

item.title: Next stable DBD::SQLite to be released in late October
item.description: A new release of DBD::SQLite is coming this October, warns Kenichi Ishigaki. If you maintain a program using SQLite, it might be a good idea indeed to test your codebase against the current trial release. Just sayin'.

item.title: Breakfast, Lunch, Band & Social Event for Free
item.description: There will be food! And social events! And live music! Announces Stefan Hornburg, regarding the upcoming Dancer conference.

item.title: DWIM Perl for Linux 5.20.1-2 released
item.description: DWIM Perl is a binary Perl distributions with 'batteries inside'. It is core Perl + a few hundred of the most commonly used modules.

item.title: Testing timeout with cmp_ok
item.description: When can cmp_ok be useful.

item.title: Using 'like' to test without exact values
item.description: An introduction to the 'like' function provided by Test::More

item.title: Shellshock and Perl
item.description: By now everybody knows what the shellshock exploit is (or wonders why herds of sysadmins all over the world have been running around, arms flapping in abject panic, for the last few days). But what does it means for Perl? David Farrell has the answer.

item.title: Book Report - September 2014
item.description: Toby Inkster is working on a Perl book, targered at intermediate-level programmers. The book-crafting is still in its early stage, but it looks very promising.

item.title: My first Perl Mongers meeting
item.description: This month's meeting of the Thames Valley perl mongers counted one presence in their midst. A young neophyte going by the name of Neil Bowers...

item.title: YAPC::Europe 2014 Survey results are online
item.description: Barbie shares the survey results for YAPC::Europe 2014, and points out some of the most interesting statistics.

item.title: What is the Perl community?
item.description: lichtkind gives his personal answer to the question that is currently making the rounds.

item.title: Perl's Problems
item.description: There is no light without darkness. No feast without heartburn. No language without, ah, irritating parts. Dave Cross muses on what he thinks are Perl's own hercules's heels.

item.title: Test::More has lots of crazy new development that's breaking my modules
item.description: The new maintainers of Test::More have released some new trial version of the ubiquitous testing module. brian d foy asks: should cpan testers be testing, and reporting failures, of modules using these versions? A fair question, and it turns out that there are pretty good arguments for and against reporting against the bleeding edge.

item.title: CPAN Testers & pre-requisite reporting
item.description: "Reporting test failures of alpha releases: good or bad?" The discussion sparked by brian d foy continues here.

item.title: A pre-release of Pod::Readme is available on CPAN
item.description: Potentially interesting for CPAN authors: Robert Rothenberg's POD-to-README generator now has a pre-release available on CPAN.

item.title: Extended Rules to support Modern Perl in Atom symbols-view package
item.description: Thanks to Krasimir Berov, the Perl ctag support in GitHub's Atom editor just got a little bit moderner.

item.title: Cloud automation at Digital Ocean using Perl
item.description: How to use the API of Digital Ocean to start a new Droplet, do something and then shut it down again.

item.title: CPAN, mcpan, MetaCPAN
item.description: A 2 min long screencast on searching for Perl modules on Google and how to arrive to the respective page on MetaCPAN.

item.title: Perl-related events
item.description: In the following cities: Hancock (NY/USA), Itapema (SC/Brasil), Salzburg (Austria), Barcelona (Spain), London (UK)
